Sanghadisesa 
 
 This term means [violation] "involving the participation of the Community in the primary (adi) and subsequent (sesa) procedures". 
 It follows from the fact that in case of violation of any of the rules of this class, it is the Community that initially imposes punishment on the monk (including a redemptive period and a probation period), imposes it again if the monk has not fulfilled the established requirements, and when the monk has fulfilled all the requirements, removes the punishment from him. 
 This section contains 13 rules, in the case of the first nine, the monk is credited with a violation immediately after the offense is committed, in the last four only after the offender has been reprimanded three times in the form of a Community procedure.

Parajika (defeat) 
 
 The book Parivara says that this term comes from a verb meaning to lose or to be defeated. A monk who commits the four prohibited acts described in this chapter is considered to have succumbed to his mental defilements (upakkilesa) to an extent that overpowers his original goal of becoming a monk. The Vibhanga gives a number of metaphors to illustrate the irreversible nature of defeat: like a man with his head cut off like a withered leaf torn from the stem… like a flat stone broken in two, which cannot be united… like a palm tree with its top cut off, unable to continue growth. A monk who commits any of these prohibited acts is irreversibly excommunicated from the life of the monastic community and is no longer considered a monk.

SUGATA SPAN AND SUGATA ELBOW 
 
 SPAND is the distance between the edge of the little finger and the edge of the thumb when the hand and fingers are spread apart. 
 ELBOW is the distance from the elbow to the edge of the middle finger. According to the Theravada Vinaya, there are three types of measures. 
 
 1 Standard Men`s Measures (Pakati Purisa) – Measurements taken according to the body size of a standard man in a society are called Standard Men`s Measures. The span and cubit of such a man are defined as an ordinary man`s span and elbow. 
 
 2 Average men`s measure (majjhima purisa) - Measures that are one and a half times (x 1 1/2) higher than ordinary men`s measures are called average men`s measures. The span of Majjhima Purish is one and a half times the arm span of Pakati Purish, and the elbow of Majjhima Purish is equal to one and a half times the size of an ordinary male elbow. The middle men`s measures in the commentaries are also known as carpenter`s (vaḍhakī) measures. 
 
 3 Measure of sugata. Measures three times larger than the average male measures are called sugata measures. a span of sugata is equal to three average spans, and a cubit of sugata is equal to three average male cubits. 
 
 The size of the kuti is indicated in sugata arm spans in accordance with the cutikara training rule. Length of kuti = 12 hand spans sugata = 36 medium hand spans of men = 54 standard hand spans of men. 
 
 Inner width of kuti = 7 sugata hand spans = 21 average man`s hand spans = 31 1/2 standard man`s hand spans.

Actions that are not violations. Origin story 
 
 At that time, the householder, the owner of delicious food, regularly donated it to the Community, the four monks every day. One day he happened to visit the monastery on some business. He went to the Venerable Dabba Mallaputta, approaching, he respectfully greeted him and sat aside... Venerable Dabba Mallaputta encouraged...his discussion of the Dhamma. Then the householder, the owner of the delicious food, ... asked Dabbu Mallaputta: “Who, venerable one, is scheduled to receive the food offering in our house tomorrow?” To the followers of Mettiya and Bhummaji (§), householder. Mettiya and Bhummajya were among the leaders of the "group of six monks" named after the number of leaders notorious for their shameless behavior, the instigators of many excesses that forced the Buddha to formulate rules of teaching. This upset the householder, the owner of the gourmet food. Thinking: “How can these bad monks eat in our house?”, he returned home and ordered his slave: “Hey! For those who come for breakfast tomorrow, prepare a mat at the gate and serve them porridge of husked rice with brine.” “Yes, master,” answered the slave. At that time the followers of Mettiya and Bhummaji said to each other: “Yesterday we were scheduled to have breakfast at the house of the householder, the owner of the gourmet food. Tomorrow he will serve us along with his wives and children. Some of them will offer us rice, some will offer us curry, some will offer us oils, some will offer us seasonings. Rejoicing, they were unable to sleep as much as they had planned that night. The next day, early in the morning, ... they went to the house of the householder - the owner of the gourmet food. The slave noticed their approach from afar. Seeing them, having prepared a mat for them at the gate, she told them: “Sit down, dear ones.” A thought occurred to the followers of Mettia and Bhummaji: “There is no doubt that the food is not ready yet, that is why we are forced to sit at the gate.” Then the slave served them porridge from husked rice with brine, saying: “Eat, dear ones.” "Sister, we are here for a regular meal." “I know you are here for a regular meal. But yesterday the householder ordered me: “Hey! For those who come for breakfast tomorrow, prepare a mat at the gate and serve them porridge of husked rice with brine.” “So eat, dear ones.” Then the followers of Mettiya and Bhummaji said to each other: “Yesterday a householder, owner of delicious food, came to the monastery and met Dabba Mallaputta. No doubt Dabba Mallaputta has turned him against us." Disappointed, they were unable to eat as much as they had planned. Then... they returned to the monastery and, having put away their chivars and bowls, went outside the gates of the monastery, and having built a canopy from their sangati, they squatted under it (§) - silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, heads bowed, thoughtful, at a loss. “Then Mettiya bhikkhuni came up to them... and said: “I greet you, dear ones.” But when she said this, they did not answer. And for the second time... And for the third time she said: “I greet you, dear ones.” And for the third time they did not answer. "Did I insult you, dear ones? Why don`t you answer me?" "Because you, sister, are indifferent while Dabba Mallaputta treats us like dirt." "What can I do?" "If you wish, you can persuade the Blessed One to banish Dabba Mallaputta on that very day." "What can I do? How can i do this?" "Go ahead, sister. Go to the Blessed One and say: “This is inappropriate, Venerable One, and wrong. A place without fear, without harm, without danger, has now become a place where there is fear, where there is harm, where there is danger. From where there was calm, a stormy wind is now blowing. The water seems to be on fire. I was raped by the respected Dabba Mallaputta." “As you say, dear ones.” (And she left to follow their orders)." This is just the beginning of the story the origin of this rule, which is one of the longest and most controversial stories of the Vinaya. After Mettiya Bhikkhuni made her accusation, the Buddha called a meeting of the Sangha to resolve the issue with Venerable Dabba Mallaputta. He, being one who attained arahantship at the age of seven, answered truthfully that he could not remember ever having indulged in sexual intercourse even in his sleep, much less while awake. The Buddha then told the Sangha to expel Mettiya Bhikkhuni and interrogate her instigators, after which he returned to his abode. When the monks expelled her, the followers of Mettia and Bhummaji told them: “Friends, do not expel Mettiya bhikkhuni. She has not done anything wrong. It was provoked by us, we were upset, unhappy and wanted him to fall." “Do you mean that you wrongly accused the Venerable Dabba Mallaputta of a parajika class offense?” "Yes friends". Then the monks indignantly, and complained, and murmured: “How can the followers of Mettiya and Bhummajī unjustifiably accuse the Venerable Dabba Mallaputta of the offense of the parajika class?” 
 

However, for centuries after the canon was compiled, many people became indignant and complained more about the Buddha`s attitude towards Mettiya bhikkhunis. According to the commentary, her expulsion was one of the controversial issues that separated the Abhayagiri Vihara monks from the Mahavihara monks located in the former capital of Sri Lanka - Anuradhapura. Even modern scholars have objected to the Buddha`s treatment of Mittiya bhikkhunis in this way and have interpreted this passage as a "monastic interpretation", as if the Buddha himself was not a monk and the entire Canon was not the work of monks and nuns. The commentary states that the Buddha did this because he knew that if he treated her less harshly, the followers of Mettiya and Bhummaji would never reveal that they had incited her to make an accusation, and the truth would never come out. This would lead some people to secretly believe that Venerable Dabba Mallaputta was guilty and, due to his being an arahant, it would cause them long-term harm and harm.

This rule is almost the same as the previous one and includes the same factors, with the exception of one of the clauses in the "Efforts" section: "unfounded accusation" here becomes "accusation based on a circumstance (adhikaraṇa) relating to another case." The phrase sounds strange, but the origin story provides a perfect example of what it means. 
 
 The exact difference between the two rules is this: in the case of an unfounded accusation, someone did not see that the violation was committed, did not hear or suspect about it; or someone changed the status of the evidence, if any, - for example, someone speaks of what he suspected as something he heard, or of what he heard as something he saw. In the case of an accusation based on a circumstance related to another matter, someone saw an act that would have been an offense if it had been committed by a monk, and someone does not substitute status of evidence, but distorts the facts of the case. 
 

Vibhanga lists ten factors that can be used as tricks to misrepresent facts. 
 

They are:

Considering the way in which Vibhanga illustrates these factors in action, they are divided into two classes:

1) An example of using a misdemeanor as a ploy:
 one sees monk Y actually committing a violation. Although one perceives this as a lesser offense, he exaggerates the charge to the level of parajika. For example, someone sees him getting into an argument with monk Z and, in a fit of anger, striking Z on the head. Z loses consciousness, falls to the floor and suffers a severe concussion, which leads to his death. Since Y`s intention was simply to hurt Z and not to kill him, he takes upon himself only pacittiya. If one realizes the nature of Y`s intention and the fact that the punishment is pacittiya, but still accuses him of committing parajika, one will accept sanghadisesa, according to the rule in question. For ease of remembering, the use of this trick can be called “one person, another violation.” 
 

2) An example of using any of the other nine factors as a trick: X, who may or may not be a monk, has something in common with monk Y - they are both tall, short, dark-skinned, fair-haired, they have the same names, they are students of the same mentor, live in the same dwelling, have outwardly similar bowls or robes, etc. One sees X performing an action which, if he were a monk, would amount to a parajika violation; on the basis of the similarity between X and monk Y, someone claims to have seen Y performing parajika. For example, X and Y are both very high. Late at night, someone sees X and realizes that X is stealing tools from the monastery storeroom. Someone has a grudge against Y and therefore accuses him of being a thief, saying: "I saw a big tall guy stealing tools and he looked just like you." Surely it was you." 
 For ease of remembering, the use of this trick can be called “violation of this, the person is different.” 
 

None of the texts mention the double trick scenario - that is, "another violation, another person", but judging by the way Vibhanga defines the circumstance pertaining to another matter, a double trick would also meet the definition. 
 

In other words, if someone who saw X making lustful contact with a woman accuses monk Y, who has the same generic name as X, of having committed sexual intercourse, then the case would seem to fall under this rule. A case that does not fall under this rule is based on the fact that someone sees or hears Y doing something that has some resemblance to a violation, but in fact is not one. For example, someone overhears the Vinaya instructions that a monk is reading tells some new monks, citing, by way of illustration, some of the statements that may be considered claims to superpowers. Since this is not a violation, it cannot be what would otherwise be a circumstance (adhikaraṇa) relating to another matter used as a ruse." In shortened terms, this can be called “that person, there are no violations.” If later, having understood the situation, someone accuses the monk of violating Pr 4, the accusation will be considered unfounded, and thus fall under the previous rule (Sg 8). 
 

The rest of the explanations of this rule are exactly the same as in the previous rule, except that in the clauses as to what is not an offense, Vibhanga states that if one, either himself or by causing someone else to do so, makes an accusation Based on what one actually perceives as a wrongdoing, there is no wrongdoing, even if the circumstances turn out to be related to another matter. 
 For example, from the examples already given: someone sees X stealing tools in the dark, and, because of his resemblance to Y, actually thinks that Y is the thief. Someone sees Y deal a fatal blow to Z and actually believes that Y`s intention was to kill Z. In any of these cases, if one accuses Y of violating the class of parajika, he is not committing any violation regardless of how things turned out, although, as in the previous rule, one must be careful to ask Y`s permission before making the accusation, and not have the intention of offending him.

Description of the training rule 
 
 Bhedānuvattaka training rule describes the offence that will be committed by the bhikkhus who will adapt to supporting the efforts of the bhikkhu who favours causing schism within the Saṅgha. It also enlightens monks on how to act in order to prevent a schism. When a certain bhikkhu attempts to cause schism within the order, bhikkhus who favour his idea and support him, praise him and try to increase his alliance are called saṅghabhedānuvattaka. Once aware of such monks, the other bhikkhus must advise them against getting together with the bhikkhu causing schism within the order. The bhikkhus who do not do so will commit a dukkaṭa offence. If they do not abandon their following, when being advised as such, the samanubhāsanakamma must be performed. Even still, if such ideas are not abandoned, the bhikkhus who are adapted will have committed a saṅghādisesa offence. On this occasion, even if there are many bhikkhus who favours causing schism within the order, the samanubhāsanakamma must be performed at one time for a maximum of three bhikkhus only. The presence of four or more bhikkhus are defined as Saṅgha according to Vinaya. If the Saṅgha performs a vinayakamma for four or more bhikkhus, it would appear as if the Saṅgha performed a vinayakamma for another group of Saṅgha. Therefore, in a given instance, the samanubhāsanakamma can only be performed for a maximum of three bhikkhus. The other information related to this training rule could be understood as explained under the saṅghabheda training rule. 
 

Once the Buddha was residing at the Veḷuvana monastery in Rājagaha. During that time, Venerable Devadatta was attempting to cause schism between the Saṅgha. One who are virtuous criticized Devadatta for his evil acts saying, “Devadatta is preaching a wrong doctrine. He is preaching a wrong discipline. How to Devadatta attempts to bread the unity within the Saṅgha?”. Hearing this criticism, friends of Devadatta such as Venerable Kokālika tried to prevent monks from accusing Devadatta; “Friends, please do not say so. Devadatta is preaching a correct doctrine. He is preaching correct discipline. He is acting so also having taken our consent and known our desire. We like what he does”. Then other monks who were virtuous and liked the unity of the Saṅgha criticized these monks who followed Devadatta. Having known the news, the Buddha declared the bhedānuvattaka training rule in order to prevent monks from following another monk who is attempting a schism with the Saṅgha order.

Once the Buddha was residing at the Jetavana monastery in Sāvatthi. During that time, two monks Venerable Assaji and Punabbasuka were living in a monastery in the district called Kīṭāgiri. They were having improper associations with lay devotees and did the acts such as growing flower trees and so forth. They also acted in ways that are utterly inappropriate to monks. On another occasion, one virtuous monk after finishing his rains retreat in the county called Kāsī was on his way to meet the Buddha and to pay homage. During the journey, he entered the district called Kīṭāgiri. That monk having dressed nicely, in a morning, went for alms round in the district of Kīṭāgiri. However, due to frequent association with monks like Assaji and Punabbasuka lay devotees could not recognize the value of abiding the Vinaya rules. So, they talked bad about this monk who was not laughing with them and who was going for alms with eyes casted down. Instead, the lay devotees praised monks like Assaji and Punabbasuka who were talkative and greeted lay devotees well whenever they meet them. One wise lay devotee saw the monk, approached him and asked, “Venerable Sir, was it easy for you to find food?”. The monk replied that it was not easy to obtain food. Then this lay devotee invited the monk to his house and offered him a meal. He, then, informed all the bad behaviors of the monks led by Venerable Assaji and Punabbasuka. He also requested the monk to report the Buddha all what he had said. After reaching Sāvatthi, the particular monk informed the Buddha about what he learned from the lay devotee who offered him food. On listening to this, the Buddha advised Venerable Sāriputta and Moggallāna to go to Kīṭāgiri and to do a vinayakamma called pabbājanīyakamma to all the monks led by Venerable Assaji and Punabbasuka. It was an uphill task for the monks led by two chief disciples to perform the relevant vinayakamma to the group of monks living in Kīṭāgiri. In the end they managed to do the pabbājanīyakamma. However, the monks led by Assaji and Punabbasuka were not happy with the vinayakamma and did not submit to it. They did not ask for forgiveness, but criticized the monks who did the vinayakamma. When this was informed to the Buddha, declared the kuladūska training rule prohibiting monks from not submitting to the pabbājanīyakamma that has been done righteously. 
 

Factors 
 
 In order for an offence to be committed under this training rule, the following four elements must be fulfilled. 
 1. Stating that the bhikkhus who performed the pabbājanīyakamma did so out of agati 
 2. Righteously conducting the samanubhāsanakamma 
 3. Completing the recitation of the kammavācā thrice 
 4. Not abandoning the idea that the bhikkhus have been affected by agati 
 

Kuladūsana 
 
 The Pārājikā Pāḷi indicates that there are eight acts in which corruption of acquaintances could occur. 
 1. Pupphadāna – Giving flowers to the laity 
 2. Phaladāna – Giving fruits to the laity 
 3. Cuṇṇadāna – Giving concoctions to the laity 
 4. Mattikādāna – Giving clay to the laity 
 5. Dantakaṭṭhadāna – Giving teeth cleaning material to the laity 
 6. Veḷudāna – Giving cane to the laity 
 7. Vejjakamma – Providing medical services for the laity 
 8. Jaṅghapesanikā – Carrying messages of the laity 
 If bhikkhus engage in the above acts in order to treat lay acquaintances, dukkaṭa offences will be committed. If objects offered to the Saṅgha are given out of thoughts of one’s own superiority, a tullaccaya offence will be committed. If an item that belongs to the Saṅgha is given out of stealthy thoughts, it will be deemed an act of stealing, and the type of offence committed must be determined according to the value of the item given. 
 

Pāpasamācāra 
 
 The Pārājikā Pāḷi also specifies pāpasamācāra. The pāpasamācāra as indicated under the kuladūsana training rule are as follows. 
 1. Mālāvacchaṃ ropeti, ropāpeti – Planting flowers and getting them planted 
 2. Mālāvacchaṃ siñcati, siñcāpeti – Watering flower plants and getting them watered 
 3. Mālāvacchaṃ ocināti, ocināpeti – Plucking flowers and getting them plucked 
 4. Mālāvacchaṃ gantheti, gnathāpeti – making garlands and getting them made 
 The acts mentioned above are inappropriate for bhikkhus only in the instance where they are done to treat lay acquaintances. Engaging in such acts is condemned by the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas and Arahants. It is appropriate to plant flowers for monastic purposes as per rules of Vinaya. 
 

Pabbājanīyakamma 
 
 When a bhikkhu or bhikkhunī constantly engages in acts of kuladūsana as indicated above, the Buddha has instructed that the pabbājanīyakamma must be performed on them. If a pabbājanīyakamma is performed on a bhikkhu or bhikkhunī, he or she must not reside in the monastery staying in which he engaged on those acts. Moreover, he or she must not go on begging for alms rounds in that village of which the correct faith of devotees was destroyed. In the instance of residing in the same monastery after the pabbājanīyakamma, he or she must not even go on begging rounds in the village nearby. Even though residing in a nearby monastery is possible, in the instance of residing in a nearby monastery, he must not go on piṇḍapāta in the same village. While residing in a nearby monastery, it is possible to go on begging rounds in the nearby village. In addition, a bhikkhu or bhikkhunī who has undergone the pabbājanīyakamma must follow certain Vinaya practices. 
 

Samanubhāsanakamma 
 
 A bhikkhu or bhikkhunī who has undergone the pabbājanīyakamma due to acts of destroying the correct faith of devotees, must conform to that correct vinayakamma. However, sometimes, defensive bhikkhus or bhikkhunīs who oppose the vinayakamma may not conform to it in the appropriate manner by accusing the Saṅgha who performed the vinayakamma that the formal disciplinary act was performed out of desire (chanda), anger (dosa), fear (bhaya) and ignorance (moha) in a prejudiced manner.The Buddha preached that the samanubhāsanakamma should be performed for such bhikkhus in such instances. Bhikkhus or bhikkhunī who have undergone the pabbājanīyakamma, still do not conform to it, the other bhikkhus must offer advice to them to make them abandon their ideas. It is great if such ideas are dispelled, when advice is given. If not, samanubhāsanakamma must be performed. It is great if such ideas are dispelled during the performance of the samanubhāsanakamma. However, if not, by the end of the samanubhāsanakamma, the particular bhikkhu or bhikkhunī will have committed a saṅghādisesa offence. 
 
 A saṅghādisesa offence will be committed when a bhikkhu who has undergone the pabbājanīyakamma, does not agree or adapt to it and accuses stating “The bhikkhus who performed the vinayakamma are affected by the four types of agati” etc. and does not abandon his ideas even while the samanubhāsanakamma is being done on him. The saṅghādisesa offence is not committed due to the acts of kuladūsana and pāpasamācāra. Each act of kuladūsana and pāpasamācāra entails a dukkaṭa offence only.
